title: The Amazing Race Australia 3
text:
The Amazing Race Australia 3 is the third season of the Australian <a href="reality%20television">reality television</a> <a href="game%20show">game show</a> "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%20Australia">The Amazing Race Australia</a>", the Australian version of "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%20%28American%20TV%20series%29">The Amazing Race</a>". Officially titled The Amazing Race Australia v New Zealand, featuring ten teams of two in a pre-existing relationship (five from <a href="Australia">Australia</a> and five from <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>), in a race around the world to win the grand prize of A$250,000.
The show premiered on Australia's <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> on 4 August 2014 after "<a href="The%20X%20Factor%20%28Australian%20TV%20series%29">The X-Factor</a>", and on New Zealand's <a href="TVNZ%202">TV2</a> on 5 August 2014 after <a href="My%20Kitchen%20Rules%20%28series%205%29">"My Kitchen Rules" 5</a>.
Australian intensive care nurses Daniel Little and Ryan Thomas were the winners of this season.
Production.
Development and Filming.
On 14 August 2012, <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> announced it was looking for contestants for a third series of "The Amazing Race Australia". Despite calling for contestant applications, the show was absent in the Seven Network's 2013 upfronts and was replaced by an unsuccessful <a href="The%20Mole%20%28Australian%20season%206%29">revival</a> of the <a href="The%20Mole%20%28Australian%20TV%20series%29">Australian version of "The Mole"</a>.
The series was renewed again on 22 October 2013. It was also announced that Seven's in-house production company, Seven Productions, would produce the series. ActiveTV, the production company involved in the show's first two production, would no longer be involved.
Filming began in March 2014 at <a href="Uluru">Uluru</a> in <a href="Ulu%E1%B9%9Fu-Kata%20Tju%E1%B9%AFa%20National%20Park">Uluṟu-Kata Tjuṯa National Park</a>. This season travelled across six continents and ten countries covering over , marking the first time that one of the international versions of "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race">The Amazing Race</a>" traveled to all six inhabited continents. This racecourse was the longest among the non-American versions and third longest overall behind the courses from "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%205">The Amazing Race 5</a>" and "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%209">The Amazing Race 9</a>".
Replacing marked for elimination, the <a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%23Non-elimination%20legs">Speed Bump</a> was introduced during this third series. It required the team that finished last in a non-elimination leg to perform an additional task at some point during the next leg. The <a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%23Salvage%20Pass">Salvage Pass</a> returned; however, it was awarded to the team that arrived first in the sixth leg rather than the first.
Casting.
Applications for the third edition originally opened during the <a href="The%20Amazing%20Race%20Australia%202">second season</a>, despite the show not being officially renewed by Seven Network. When the show was officially renewed for 2014, applications opened again, including to citizens of <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. Applicants who applied previously were given a chance to update their application. This second round of applications ended on 22 December 2013.
Jesse O'Brien was previously a contestant on the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Idol%20%28season%201%29">first season</a> of "<a href="New%20Zealand%20Idol">New Zealand Idol</a>". He withdrew from the season to attend to the birth of his daughter. He then returned for the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Idol%20%28season%202%29">second season</a>, where he placed fourth. He participated with his wife, Cat O'Brien.
<a href="Elizabeth%20Grant%20%28anthropologist%29">Elizabeth Grant</a>, a well-known Australian anthropologist and academic, participated with her son, Todd. She was injured during Leg 2 and was subsequently eliminated.
During Leg 6, Tyson Smith proposed to Sally Yamamoto on their fourth anniversary, and she accepted.
Future appearances.
In 2019, Jonathan "Jono" Trenberth appeared on the third season of "Married at First Sight NZ".
Marketing.
<a href="Kathmandu%20%28company%29">Kathmandu</a>, <a href="John%20West%20Foods">John West Tuna</a> and <a href="Virgin%20Australia">Virgin Australia</a> were the sponsors for this series.
Results.
The following teams participated in the season, with their relationships at the time of filming. Note that this table is not necessarily reflective of all content broadcast on television due to inclusion or exclusion of some data. Placements are listed in finishing order:
Episode title quotes.
Episode titles are often taken from quotes made by the racers.
Prizes.
Prizes were awarded throughout the season, generally to the team placing first in each leg but also for special tasks that took place throughout the season. Most prizes were sponsored by <a href="Virgin%20Australia">Virgin Australia</a> and their affiliated products.
Race summary.
Leg 1 (Australia → New Zealand).
Airdate: 4 August 2014 (AU); 5 August 2014 (NZ)
In this series' first Nation vs. Nation task, the ten teams were divided into two groups of five teams based on their nationality to compete in a "Trans-Tasman <a href="tug%20of%20war">tug of war</a>". The first nation to pull their opponents' flag past a marker would be given a 10-minute head-start to the airport.
In this season's first Roadblock, one team member had to navigate a <a href="tractor">tractor</a> through a slalom course and move four <a href="hay">hay</a> bales into a marked area. Then, they had to go to a <a href="sheep">sheep</a> paddock and find the sheep with the exact match of the other half of their ring from the rafting challenge.
Leg 2 (New Zealand → Cambodia).
Airdate: 11 August 2014 (AU); 12 August 2014 (NZ)
In this leg's Roadblock, one team member had to count the <a href="Bhikkhu">monks</a> wearing red and yellow <a href="Buddhist%20prayer%20beads">prayer beads</a>. Once all monks were counted, team members collected an offering to present to two other monks inside the temple. The racer had to pick one of the two monks to give their answer, but one of the monks would lie even if the racer had the right answer. Once the truth-telling monk was given the correct answer (26), he would give them their next clue.
This season's first Detour was a choice between Shrimp or Shoot. In Shrimp, teams had to collect of <a href="shrimp">shrimp</a> from <a href="fish%20trap">fish trap</a>s in <a href="Tonl%C3%A9%20Sap">Tonlé Sap</a> to receive their next clue from a fisherman. In Shoot, teams had to travel to the floating village of Chong Khneas and find the local pool hall, where they had to level out a <a href="Pool%20%28cue%20sports%29">pool table</a> and then sink five balls, while competing against a local player, to receive their next clue.
Leg 3 (Cambodia → Thailand).
Airdate: 18 August 2014 (AU); 19 August 2014 (NZ)
This leg's Detour was a choice between Climb Up or Drill Down. For both Detour options, teams had to travel by <a href="long-tail%20boat">long-tail boat</a> to Phra Nang Beach. In Climb Up, both team members had to scale a sheer rock face to retrieve an "Amazing Race" flag, which they could exchange their for their next clue. In Drill Down, teams had to first build a <a href="Drill%23Hand%20tools">hand drill</a> and then use it to extract enough <a href="coconut">coconut</a> juice from a pile of coconuts to fill a container to a marked line to receive their next clue.
In this leg's Roadblock, teams had to travel to a marked area of the sea, where one team member had dive down to the seafloor to retrieve a <a href="Corbicula%20fluminea">golden clam</a> with a <a href="pearl">pearl</a> that contained their next clue.
Leg 4 (Thailand → Namibia).
Airdate: 25 August 2014 (AU); 26 August 2014 (NZ)
In this leg's Roadblock, one team member had to cut up a pile of <a href="offal">offal</a> and, following an example, prepare the correct quantity to feed to a pride of lions and receive their next clue.
This leg's Detour was a choice between Pipe or Poo. For both Detour options, teams had to travel to a local village by donkey cart. In Pipe, teams had to use a traditional bush method to make fire. Once teams had built enough fire to allow the village chief to light his pipe, they would receive their next clue. In Poo, each team member had to participate in a local game called "<a href="Kudu%20dung-spitting">bokdrool</a>", which required them to spit elephant dung pellets away and across a line to receive their next clue.
Leg 5 (Namibia → Russia).
Airdate: 25 August 2014 (AU); 2 September 2014 (NZ)
In this leg's Roadblock, one team member had to decipher a message communicated by the ship commander from the top of the battleship in <a href="flag%20semaphore">flag semaphore</a> and written in the <a href="Russian%20alphabet">Russian Cyrillic alphabet</a> ( ) to receive their next clue.
This leg's Detour was a choice between Cossack or Coat Rack. In Cossack, teams had to learn the traditional <a href="Hopak">Cossack dance</a>. Once the instructor was satisfied with teams' effort, they received their next clue. In Coat Rack, teams had to search through a pile of over three hundred tags to find the one that was missing. They had to then search the coats in the coat room for the missing tag. Once teams handed the correct missing tag to the attendant, she would hand them their next clue.
Leg 6 (Russia).
Airdate: 1 September 2014 (AU); 9 September 2014 (NZ)
In this season's second Nation vs. Nation task, teams from each country had to team up, select three <a href="matryoshka%20doll">matryoshka doll</a>s, and search among hundreds of other nesting dolls in five separate houses to find the four smaller pieces that belonged to each of the dolls they chose. Once the three teams had collected all twelve pieces, they all would receive their next clue.
This leg's Detour was a choice between Boil or Build. In Boil, teams had to fill a Russian outdoor bathing kettle with water until it reached the marked line and also had to use wood and paper scraps to light a fire underneath it. Once the kettle was full and the fire was alight, teams had to submerge themselves in the icy water before receiving their next clue. In Build, teams had to stack all of the firewood provided, following a traditional method, within a marked area to receive their next clue.
In this leg's Roadblock, teams travelled to the North Hope Sled Dog Center, where one team member had to ride a <a href="dog%20sled">dog sled</a> of <a href="Siberian%20Husky">Siberian Huskies</a> and <a href="Alaskan%20Malamute">Alaskan Malamute</a>s around a slalom course through the forest to receive their next clue.
Leg 7 (Russia → Portugal).
Airdate: 8 September 2014 (AU); 16 September 2014 (NZ)
This leg's Detour was a choice between Wet or Dry. In Wet, teams made their way to a section of the Lisbon streets celebrating the "Agitagueda Art Festival", where thousands of <a href="umbrella">umbrella</a>s were hung above the streets, and had to count all of the yellow umbrellas (297). When teams wrote the correct answer on a chalkboard and presented it to a judge at a café on Rua da Regueira, they would receive their next clue. In Dry, teams had to find a group of women on the streets with had a laundry basket that had the laundry lady's name attached. Teams then had to search among the clotheslines above the nearby streets for the article of clothing with a name tag listing their laundry lady to receive their next clue.
In this leg's Roadblock, one team member had to pick up a large fish, of <a href="mussel">mussel</a>s, and of <a href="octopus">octopus</a> and carry them across town to Restaurante A Económica. Once they delivered their seafood, they would then be served a traditional <a href="Portuguese%20cuisine%23Fish%20and%20seafood">Portuguese fish stew</a>, "cataplana", which they had to eat to receive their next clue.
Leg 8 (Portugal → Croatia).
Airdate: 15 September 2014 (AU); 23 September 2014 (NZ)
In this season's only Fast Forward, teams had to travel to the Dominican Monastery, where they were instructed to collect three <a href="Holy%20card">prayer cards</a> from three different local churches, deliver them to Muški Frizerski Salon, and would discover that they had to get a <a href="tonsure">tonsure</a> haircut for men or a nun haircut for women. The first team to do so would win the Fast Forward award.
For their Speed Bump, Ashleigh & Jarrod had to properly knot a necktie on each other, a <a href="bow%20tie">bow tie</a> and a <a href="Necktie%23Four-in-hand">four-in-hand</a>, before they could continue racing.
In this leg's first Roadblock, one team member had to <a href="Australian%20rappel">abseil face-first</a> down the side of Fort Bokar to receive their next clue.
In this leg's second Roadblock, the team member who did not perform the previous Roadblock had to climb up Fort Saint John using an <a href="Ascender%20%28climbing%29">ascender</a> to receive their next clue.
Leg 9 (Croatia → Argentina).
Airdate: 15 September 2014 (AU); 30 September 2014 (NZ)
In this leg's Roadblock, one team member had to navigate a <a href="sulky">sulky</a>, a horse-drawn carriage, to a <a href="polo">polo</a> field, where they had to properly dress and saddle a <a href="Polo%20pony">polo horse</a> for competition to the satisfaction of a local polo player to receive their next clue.
This season's final Detour, which paid tribute to Argentina's cultural heritage, was a choice between Tango or Tribute. In Tango, teams had to search through <a href="Carlos%20Gardel">Carlos Gardel's</a> biography, "Tangos Que Cantó Gardel", for a card directing them to Pasaje de la Defensa, where both team members had to learn to perform a complex <a href="tango">tango</a> routine. Once they could dance to the satisfaction of a judge, teams would receive their next clue. In Tribute, teams had to search page 197 of <a href="Diego%20Maradona">Diego Maradona's</a> biography, "Cebollita Maradona", to find his home stadium <a href="La%20Bombonera">La Bombonera</a>, where a football player instructed them in <a href="Rioplatense%20Spanish">Spanish</a>, "Find in the book, the hospital where Diego Maradona was born. Come back with the answer." Once teams found the answer in their book, Hospital Interzonal General de Agudos Evita, the football player then handed them a picture of <a href="Eva%20Per%C3%B3n">Eva Perón</a> directing them to the site of her grave, <a href="La%20Recoleta%20Cemetery">La Recoleta Cemetery</a>, where they would find their next clue.
Leg 10 (Argentina → United States → Australia).
Airdate: 25 September 2014 (AU); 7 October 2014 (NZ)
In this season's final Roadblock, one team member had to find the nine items worn or held by the Pit Stop greeters from a vast array of items and place the items in the correct order teams encountered them atop <a href="barrel">barrel</a>s to receive their final clue. The correct order of items was:
Ratings.
Australian Ratings.
All ratings data in Australia are taken from the five major metropolitan centres. Data from regional areas is not accounted for. Due to poor programming from Channel 7 there is no set time-slot, but the start time for the show was around 8:40 p.m. to 9:10 p.m. Times are taken from Electronic Programming Guides which still may not be accurate as to the real start time. Despite the lower ratings compared to the previous series, the show rated well in time shift, often being among the highest viewership gainers for the night.
